verses.text: Pursue love, and earnestly seek the spiritual gifts, especially that you may prophesy.
verses.comment: Paul urges believers to make love their highest aim, but also to desire spiritual gifts, giving prominence to prophecy, which benefits the Church directly.

verses.text: For the one who speaks in a tongue speaks not to men but to God, for no one understands him; but in the Spirit he speaks mysteries.
verses.comment: Speaking in tongues, while a spiritual gift, is not understood by others unless interpreted. The spiritual experience is genuine, but its benefit to others needs interpretation.

verses.text: But the one who prophesies speaks to people for their strengthening, encouragement, and comfort.
verses.comment: Prophecy directly builds up the Church, offering practical benefits. Notice how communal edification is a core value.

verses.text: The one who speaks in a tongue builds up himself, but the one who prophesies builds up the Church.
verses.comment: Gifts ought to serve the whole body. This underscores the importance of the Church as the visible community of believers.

verses.text: Now I want you all to speak in tongues, but even more to prophesy. The one who prophesies is greater than the one who speaks in tongues, unless someone interprets, so that the Church may be built up.
verses.comment: Interpretation is key—gifts should strengthen the Church collectively, not just the individual.

verses.text: Now, brothers, if I come to you speaking in tongues, how will I help you unless I bring you a revelation or knowledge or prophecy or teaching?
verses.comment: Paul stresses intelligibility and practical value, setting criteria for effective ministry.

verses.text: Even lifeless things that make sounds, such as flute or harp, if they do not produce clear notes, how will what is played be recognized?
verses.comment: Paul illustrates with musical instruments, showing that meaning and clarity are crucial for edification.

verses.text: And if the bugle gives an uncertain sound, who will prepare for battle?
verses.comment: The message must be clear and recognizable, especially in spiritual warfare.

verses.text: So also, unless you speak clearly with your tongue, how will what is being said be understood? You will just be speaking into the air.
verses.comment: Communication is meant for mutual understanding and spiritual profit, not confusion.

verses.text: There are undoubtedly many kinds of languages in the world, and none is without meaning.
verses.comment: References the diversity of human languages, recalling Babel. Each has purpose and meaning.

verses.text: If I do not understand the meaning of the language, I will be a foreigner to the speaker, and the speaker a foreigner to me.
verses.comment: Unity in worship depends on mutual understanding.

verses.text: So also, since you are eager for spiritual gifts, seek to excel in building up the Church.
verses.comment: The Church, as Christ’s body, must be the central focus of spiritual gifts.

verses.text: Therefore, let the one who speaks in a tongue pray that he may interpret.
verses.comment: Paul advocates for prayerful seeking of intelligibility in spiritual matters.

verses.text: For if I pray in a tongue, my spirit prays, but my mind is unfruitful.
verses.comment: Spiritual gifts function in both heart and intellect; fruitful worship involves both.

verses.text: What then? I will pray with the spirit, but I will also pray with the mind; I will sing with the spirit, but I will also sing with the mind.
verses.comment: Balanced spiritual life involves heart and mind in harmony, reflected in communal worship practices.

verses.text: Otherwise, if you give thanks in the spirit, how can anyone in the position of an outsider say 'Amen' to your thanksgiving since he does not know what you are saying?
verses.comment: 'Amen' is a communal affirmation; intelligibility matters in public prayer.

verses.text: You may be giving thanks well enough, but the other person is not being built up.
verses.comment: Effective worship builds up those who participate, reflecting the Church’s role as the faith community.

verses.text: I thank God that I speak in tongues more than all of you.
verses.comment: Though Paul values tongues, he prioritizes edification and understanding.

verses.text: But in the Church I would rather speak five words with my mind to instruct others than ten thousand words in a tongue.
verses.comment: Instruction and spiritual growth are best done in an intelligible manner that benefits the gathered church.

verses.text: Brothers, do not be children in your thinking. Be infants in evil, but in your thinking be mature.
verses.comment: Maturity in faith is encouraged, pointing towards growth and deeper spiritual understanding.

verses.text: In the Law it is written, 'By people of strange tongues and by the lips of foreigners I will speak to this people, and not even then will they listen to me,' says the Lord.
verses.comment: Quoting Isaiah, Paul shows how even miraculous signs may be ignored if not understood—underscoring the necessity of clear teaching.

verses.text: Therefore, tongues are a sign not for believers but for unbelievers, while prophecy is a sign not for unbelievers but for believers.
verses.comment: Tongues may serve as a sign to outsiders, but prophecy edifies and strengthens those already in the faith.

verses.text: So if the whole Church comes together and everyone speaks in tongues, and outsiders or unbelievers enter, will they not say that you are out of your minds?
verses.comment: Clarity and order in Church worship serve both believers and seekers, highlighting the visible, structured gathering.

verses.text: But if all prophesy, and an unbeliever or outsider enters, he is convicted by all and called to account by all.
verses.comment: Prophecy brings conviction and invites transformation—spiritual fruitfulness in the body.

verses.text: The secrets of his heart are revealed, and so, falling on his face, he will worship God and declare that God is truly among you.
verses.comment: Divine presence in the Church is witnessed through spiritual gifts and orderly worship.

verses.text: What then, brothers? When you come together, each one has a hymn, a lesson, a revelation, a tongue, or an interpretation. Let all things be done for building up.
verses.comment: Each member’s contribution is valued, but the aim is the spiritual strengthening of the entire assembled body.

verses.text: If any speak in a tongue, let it be by two or at most three, and each in turn, and let someone interpret.
verses.comment: Order and structure are emphasized, showing that authority and discipline are respected in corporate worship.

verses.text: But if there is no one to interpret, let each of them keep silent in the Church and speak to himself and to God.
verses.comment: The Church’s unity and clarity of worship are to be preserved above individual expression.

verses.text: Let two or three prophets speak, and let the others weigh what is said.
verses.comment: Test all prophecy, showing discernment and accountability, which is vital to the Church’s holiness.

verses.text: If a revelation is made to another sitting there, let the first be silent.
verses.comment: Deference to others and humility are marks of spiritual life in community.

verses.text: For you can all prophesy one by one, so that all may learn and all may be encouraged.
verses.comment: Order brings edification; spiritual gifts are for unity, not chaos.

verses.text: And the spirits of prophets are subject to prophets.
verses.comment: Self-control is expected; spiritual experience does not override communal discernment.

verses.text: For God is not a God of confusion but of peace. As in all the gatherings of the saints:
verses.comment: Divine order is contrasted with disorder; peace and harmony characterize authentic worship.

verses.text: Women should keep silent in the churches, for they are not permitted to speak, but should be in submission, as the Law also says.
verses.comment: The ancient practice of ordered worship and submission reflects spiritual order; interpret in light of other passages where women prophesy (e.g., Acts 21:9).

verses.text: If they desire to learn anything, let them ask their husbands at home; for it is shameful for a woman to speak in Church.
verses.comment: This prescribes a contextually ordered worship. Ancient norms emphasized the Church’s unity and dignity—see Priscilla’s involvement (Acts 18:26) as an exception through proper teaching.

verses.text: Or was it from you that God’s word came? Or are you the only ones it has reached?
verses.comment: The authority of the Church and the apostolic tradition exceeds personal preference or innovation.

verses.text: If anyone thinks himself to be a prophet or spiritual, let him recognize that what I write to you is a command of the Lord.
verses.comment: Apostolic authority is linked with Christ’s own authority, guiding the Church.

verses.text: If anyone does not recognize this, he is not recognized.
verses.comment: Affirms the need for doctrinal unity and the safeguarding of the apostolic faith handed down.

verses.text: So then, brothers, earnestly desire to prophesy, and do not forbid speaking in tongues.
verses.comment: Spiritual gifts are valuable, but discernment and order are essential for the Church’s life.

verses.text: But all things should be done decently and in order.
verses.comment: God’s people, gathered for worship, must reflect the divine order and holiness established by Christ’s apostles in the visible, structured Church. This verse sums up the preceding instructions, blending practical and spiritual dimensions of life together.
